Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: The Master Print: Investigating and Addressing Vulnerabilities in Fingerprint-based Authentication Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate the security of fingerprint authentication systems, especially those using partial fingerprints. A number of consumer electronic devices, such as smartphones, are beginning to incorporate fingerprint sensors for user authentication. The sensors embedded in these devices are generally very small and the resulting images are, therefore, limited in size. To compensate for the limited size, these devices often acquire multiple partial impressions (templates) of a single finger during enrollment to ensure that at least one of them will successfully match with the image obtained from the user during authentication. In some cases, the user may even be allowed to enroll multiple fingers, and the templates pertaining to these multiple fingers are associated with the same identity (i.e., one user). A user is deemed to be successfully authenticated if the partial fingerprint obtained during authentication matches with any one of the stored templates.

This project is investigating the possibility of generating a "Master Print," a synthetic or real partial fingerprint that serendipitously matches with a large number of partial impressions pertaining to multiple users. This is akin to having a Master Password that can unlock a diverse set of user accounts. In this regard, the following tasks are being conducted: (a) Analyzing the vulnerability of fingerprint authentication systems that use partial fingerprints by developing methods to generate Master Prints; (b) Models for computing the distinctiveness or uniqueness of partial fingerprints compared to full prints; (c) Methods for mitigating the vulnerability associated with the adversarial use of Master Prints.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although biometric authentication is heralded as a much awaited and welcome replacement of the "what you know" (e.g. PINs, passwords), and "what you have" (e.g. dongles, cards) paradigms, their practical deployments rely on usability trade-os that are not always fully understood. Increasing use of biometric authentication in low-cost unsupervised deployments has spawned a torrent of presentation and spoong attacks. Not only has it become easier to feed adversarial content to such systems, but also the systems themselves are deployed in congurations that may not be as secure as advertised. In this research project we demonstrated for the very first time, that dictionary attacks, the nemesis of password based authentication can also be employed against. biometric systems, This is especially true with low resolution sensors, combined with lax verication policies that prioritize usability,  employed in computing devices such as thet small fingerprint sensors in smart-phones. 

In contrast to well-known spoong, dictionary attacks do not rely on biometric samples of a targeted individual, e.g., voice recordings or latent prints, but instead exploit weaknessess of the specic biometric modality (or its deployment). They allow to target entire populations, and rely on fortuitous matches of common biometric features. This means, it is possible to ?spoof? for example, the fingerprints of subjects without actually gaining any information about their fingerprint.  The spoofing is don by using a set ios MasterPrints.  MasterPrints are a set of real or synthetic fingerprints that can fortuitouslymatch with a large number of other fingerprints.

Buildiing on our previous research demonstrating the existence of MasterPrints at the digital template level, this project was  the first work that created a synthetic MasterPrint at the image-level using a novel machine learning artchitecture  thereby making the attack inherently practical.. Fingerprint images created in this project   were able to able to spoof 23% of the subjects in well known  dataset at a 0.1% false match ate. At a 1% false match rate, the generated MasterPrints could  spoof 77% of the subjects in the dataset. The project then deveoped  at a template selection algorithm that aimed at countering a MasterPrint attack. Finally we studied the saliency of minutiae points with respect to convolutional neural networks. This analysis was conducted to determine the role of minutiae points in fingerprint matching and whether a CNN can automatically learn the significance of minutiae points, even if it had no prior knowledge about these points. This would help us understand the features that DeepMasterPrints should focus on. To this effect, a patch-based Siamese Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which does not explicitly rely on the extraction of minutiae points, was designed and trained from scratch. The features learned by this network were analyzed using Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) to determine if they correlate with the locations of minutiae points. Our experiments suggested that the proposed network automatically learns to focus on minutiae points, when available, for fingerprint matching. Thus, an automated learner without any explicit domain knowledge establishes the significance of minutiae points for fingerprint matching.

Beyond fingerprints, the project also demonstrated the vulnerability of voice based biometrics on dictionary attacks. We developed Master Voices that were optimized to match against a large number of users. We demonstrated that it is possible to find real utterances which intrinsically hold this property. Then, we developed an approach for generating Master Voices synthetically from seed utterances. Our results showed that, even in the most secure configuration, we can match 20% of females and 10% of males without any knowledge about the individuals or populations.  Overall our work has demonstrates that dictionary attacks should be considered for sensitive and high-stakes deployments of the biometric  verification technology.
